aliases.name: Lilith
aliases.meaning: Ancient night demon, first wife of Adam

description.summary: Succubus (female) and Incubus (male) are demons from medieval Christian demonology that seduce humans during sleep, drain life force through sexual encounters, and sometimes steal semen or impregnate victims.
description.full: Succubus and Incubus are sexual demons from medieval Christian demonology, with roots in earlier Mesopotamian mythology. A Succubus (female demon) seduces men during sleep, while an Incubus (male demon) seduces women. These entities are described as shape-shifters appearing as attractive humans, draining victims' life force through sexual encounters. Medieval texts claimed they could steal semen from men or impregnate women, sometimes explaining pregnancies out of wedlock or nocturnal emissions. Modern understanding attributes these experiences to sleep paralysis with hypnagogic hallucinations, though the phenomenon appears in folklore worldwide under various names including Lilith, Mara, and Alp.

etymology.origin: Latin terms from medieval Christian demonology, though the concept has much older roots in Mesopotamian mythology (Lilith, Ardat-lili)
etymology.meaning: Succubus: 'to lie beneath' (succubare); Incubus: 'to lie upon' (incubare)

appearance.common_form: Extremely attractive human of opposite sex to victim
variations: Demonic form with wings, tail, horns (rare sightings)

features.description: Ability to appear as any attractive human form
Manifests as ideal sexual partner for victim
Reported coldness despite appearance of warmth
Wings, tail, horns visible in true form

physical.morphology: No consistent physical form; appears as needed to seduce victim

abilities.description: Can appear as any human form, typically attractive to victim
Enters and controls dreams, creates vivid sexual scenarios
Drains victim's energy through sexual contact
Can remain invisible or appear only to intended victim
Medieval belief: steal semen or impregnate women

behavior.targets: Sleeping humans, particularly those in lustful or sinful states
patterns: May cause obsessive thoughts or desires
Medieval texts: more active during sinful thoughts

range.description: Worldwide phenomenon under various names, most documented in medieval Christian Europe

peak_activity_periods.description: Medieval and Renaissance Europe, widespread belief and documentation
Witch-hunting period, extensively documented in Malleus Maleficarum

temporal.modern_reports: Continues in sleep paralysis experiences and paranormal accounts

origins.cultural_roots: Ancient Mesopotamian demons (Lilith, Ardat-lili) who attacked men at night. Adopted and developed extensively in medieval Christian demonology as explanation for nocturnal emissions, illicit pregnancy, and sleep disturbances.
origins.earliest_accounts: Lilith appears in Sumerian texts circa 3000 BCE as a night demon. Jewish Talmudic texts (circa 500 CE) describe Lilith as Adam's first wife who became a demon.
origins.folklore_connections: Connected to worldwide night hag/mare traditions: Germanic Mara, Slavic Mora, Old English MÃ¦re, Greek Ephialtes

timeline.significance: Earliest documented night demon attacking men
Lilith described as Adam's first wife turned demon
Numerous accused witches confess to sexual relations with demons

history.modern_era: Modern medicine recognizes sleep paralysis with hypnagogic/hypnopompic hallucinations as the physiological basis for these experiences. The phenomenon is well-documented scientifically, though paranormal believers continue to report demonic sexual encounters.

notable.name: Merlin's Conception
notable.description: Medieval legend claims Merlin the wizard was conceived when an incubus visited his mother, a nun. This explained his magical powers as half-demonic heritage.

credibility.notes: Demonstrates medieval use of incubus to explain extraordinary abilities

sources: Geoffrey of Monmouth, Historia Regum Britanniae (1136)

notable.name: European Witch Trial Confessions
notable.description: Thousands of accused witches confessed under torture to sexual relations with demons (incubi). These confessions formed basis for convictions and executions.

credibility.notes: Demonstrates widespread belief but confessions unreliable due to torture

sources: Witch trial records, various European courts

physical.description: No physical evidence exists; phenomenon is entirely testimonial and folkloric

testimonial.name: Medieval theological and legal texts
testimonial.description: Extensive documentation in religious texts, witch-hunting manuals, and trial records
testimonial.analysis: Reflects cultural beliefs and sleep disorder experiences

paranormal.name: Genuine Demonic Entities
paranormal.description: Succubi and Incubi are real demons that sexually assault humans during sleep

paranormal.name: Astral/Spirit Entities
paranormal.description: Non-physical entities from astral plane that feed on sexual energy

scientific.name: Sleep Paralysis with Hypnagogic Hallucinations
scientific.description: Experiences are sleep paralysis episodes combined with vivid sexual hallucinations during REM sleep intrusion

scientific.name: Nocturnal Emissions Explanation
scientific.description: Medieval explanation for natural nocturnal emissions and erotic dreams
evidence_cited: Cultural need to explain without acknowledging sexuality

scientific.name: Psychological Projection
scientific.description: Projection of repressed sexual desires, particularly in sexually repressive cultures
evidence_cited: Prevalence in sexually repressive medieval Christianity

cultural.name: Social Control Mechanism
cultural.description: Belief system used to control sexual behavior and explain illicit pregnancies
evidence_cited: Explanation for pregnancy out of wedlock

folklore.beliefs: Medieval Christianity: demons could steal semen from men and use it to impregnate women, explaining both nocturnal emissions and illicit pregnancy. Offspring might be changelings or possessed.

texts: Malleus Maleficarum (1487) - Extensive discussion of incubi and succubi
Summa Theologica by Thomas Aquinas - Theological treatment
The Alphabet of Ben-Sira (700-1000 CE) - Lilith as Adam's first wife
historical.significance: Used to explain sexual experiences during sleep, pregnancies out of wedlock, and nocturnal emissions. Central to witch trial prosecutions.
historical.sensitivity_note: Historical persecution: thousands executed based partly on confessions of demonic sexual encounters (under torture)

The Monk by Matthew Lewis (1796) - Gothic demon seduction
